de.esoco.lib.logging

Class StreamLogging

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.obrel.core.RelatedObject
      • de.esoco.lib.logging.LogAspect<java.lang.String>
        • de.esoco.lib.logging.StreamLogging
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    org.obrel.core.Relatable
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    FileLogging

    public class StreamLogging
extends LogAspect<java.lang.String>
    A log aspect that writes log data to streams. The Writer to write the log records to must be provided by a Supplier function that is handed to the constructor StreamLogging.

    • Field Summary

      • Fields inherited from class de.esoco.lib.logging.LogAspect

    • Constructor Detail

      • StreamLogging

        public StreamLogging(java.util.function.Supplier<java.io.Writer> fGetWriter)
        Creates a new instance that get's the target writer from a function. If the logging target is a stream the supplier function could wrap it into an OutputStreamWriter, for example. The writer returned by the function will be closed after each access and therefore needs to be re-created (or re-opened) by each call to the supplier. This should be taken into account when creating the actual writer, e.g. by opening a FileWriter or FileOutputStream in append mode.
        Parameters:
        fGetWriter - A function that returns the target writer

    • Method Detail

      • createLogObject

        protected java.lang.String createLogObject(LogRecord rLogRecord)
        Must be implemented by subclasses to create an implementation-specific log data object from a LogRecord instance.
        Specified by:
        createLogObject in class LogAspect<java.lang.String>
        Parameters:
        rLogRecord - The log record to convert
        Returns:
        The implementation log object

      • processLogObjects

        protected void processLogObjects(java.util.Collection<java.lang.String> aLogs)
                          throws java.lang.Exception
        Must be implemented by subclasses to process a collection of log data objects in an implementation-specific way, e.g. by sending them to another system or store them in a database. The given collection will always contain at least one object. Multiple objects should always be process in the iteration order of the collection and the collection must not be modified by the implementation. The objects in the collection have all been created by LogAspect.createLogObject(LogRecord).

        Implementations may throw any kind of exception. The log aspect base implementation will perform a generic error handling by shutting down the aspect logging and logging a FATAL message. The implementation must still perform any cleanup of acquired resources if necessary.

        Specified by:
        processLogObjects in class LogAspect<java.lang.String>
        Parameters:
        aLogs - The log objects to process
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - If the processing fails
